STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
August 27, 2021
Jennifer Tate
Livingston County DHHS
2300 E. Grand River #1
Howell, MI 48843-7577
RE: License #: CP470201250
Investigation #: 2021C0112034
Livingston County DHHS
Dear Ms. Tate:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT

Investigation #: 2021C0112034
Complaint Receipt Date: 07/15/2021

Lansing, MI 48902

Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, FIA
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency communicated inappropriately with foster parents. There Yes
were additional concerns that agency was not completing reports
timely, was losing documents, and unjustly denied a license to
foster parents.
III. METHODOLOGY

08/26/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
Agency communicated inappropriately with foster parents. There were additional
concerns that agency was not completing reports timely, was losing documents, and
unjustly denied a license to foster parents.
INVESTIGATION:
On 7/15/2021 I received an on-line complaint from Applicant A stating that Worker 1
told her that she would be approved for foster home licensing by January of 2021,
but Worker 1 has not yet completed her report. Applicant A indicated that Worker 1
initially told her that they would be approved, but later told Applicant A that she was
recommending denial of licensure. Applicant A also stated Worker 1 continually asks
for additional information from the family and asks them the same questions multiple
times.
On 7/15/2021 I reviewed Applicant A’s MiSACWIS record in which there was not a
completed licensing certification report or recommendation.
On 7/22/2021, 8/5/2021, and 8/13/2020 I interviewed Applicant A by phone.
Applicant B was also present during the calls and could be heard interjecting at
times from the background. Applicant A reported that she was applying to be
licensed in order to adopt her Godchildren who were in care in a different state.
Applicant A reported Worker 1 reported to the family upon their first meeting that
they would be licensed by January of 2021. In February of 2021, Worker 1 told the
family that the process was taking longer than expected, but that they would be
licensed by March. Worker 1 told the applicants that they would need to make
renovations to the home and would need bunkbeds prior to the home being
approved. Applicant A reported that she and Applicant B borrowed $50,000 to make
the renovation which included adding a bedroom and bathroom and that Worker 1
obtained the bunkbeds for the prospective placements in April. When the family
hadn’t heard anything from Worker 1 by May of 2021, they called Supervisor 1 who
told the family that the licensing report with recommendation would be submitted by
May 17. When Applicant A spoke to Worker 1 about the delay, Worker 1 told the
4

family that she was overwhelmed and working nights and weekends causing her to
miss time with her husband. Applicant A stated that she and Applicant B attended a
meeting with Program Manager, Supervisor 1, and Worker 1 in June during which
Worker 1 stated there were no barriers to completing her report, but she needed to
include a police report she recently received. On 7/12/2021 Applicants A & B
attended a Zoom meeting with Worker 1 and Supervisor 1 during which Worker 1
accused them of lying, failing to be forthcoming, and violating licensing rules so she
would be denying them for licensure.
Applicant A stated that Worker 1 gave the family “verbal approval” multiple times and
made several excuses as to why the licensing process was taking so long, including
other priorities taking precedence over their report.
On 7/22/2021 I interviewed Worker 1 in person. Worker 1 reported that her
relationship with Applicant A & Applicant B started out positively. She reported the
family attended orientation and submitted an application on 9/21/2020. Worker 1
stated that she initially thought the family would be licensable, which she
communicated to the family. She stated that she began to question whether they
would be licensable, which she communicated to the family in November of 2020;
however, Worker 1 also reported that she helped obtain Christmas presents for the
family’s children and assisted them in obtaining beds for the youth for whom they
were applying to take placement. She stated that she completed an initial
walkthrough of the family’s home on 1/13/2021 and informed the family that they
would need to make some repairs to their home, including replacing carpet in two
bedrooms and “updating” those rooms before they could be licensed. She stated
that the family replaced the entire 2nd floor carpeting and renovated their whole
basement, including adding an additional bedroom for which she had previously
provided them information regarding Family Incentive Grant funding requests. She
enrolled the family on 2/24/2021 and completed a second walkthrough of the home
on 4/8/2021 at which time she believed the family was licensable. She reported that
she requested updated financial information on 4/29/2021 and updated medical
statements on 5/20/2021 statements made by the physicians in the medical
statements required additional follow-up and clarification. On 6/1/2021 Worker 1 and
Supervisor 1 held a meeting with the applicants after which a request was made by
Worker 1 to meet with the assigned DCWL Central Office Consultant to discuss her
report. That meeting took place on 6/17/2021 during which DCWL Central Office
Consultant requested that additional information be obtained. On 6/17/2021 Worker
1 requested additional documents from service providers, which she reviewed on
6/28/2021. On 7/12/2021 another meeting was held with the applicants during which
Worker 1 informed them of her denial recommendation.
Worker 1 reported that she maintained regular communication with the family until
the last “several months” during which her communication lessened as she was
waiting for and reviewing records. She stated that it was possible the family believed
that she was going to recommend them for licensure prior to the July 12th meeting
for which Worker 1 felt “bad about.”
5

Worker 1 reported the licensing of Applicants A & B has taken an “exceptionally long
time” because there was a hiring freeze that resulted in Worker 1 needing to take on
additional job responsibilities. She stated that she also had an influx of new inquiries
and had other cases that took precedence over Applicants A & B, including relative
licensure, ICPC cases, and back-to-back denials. Worker 1 also stated that she had
initially reviewed the family’s DHHS history and did not have any concerns, but when
it came time to write her report, she looked at the history more closely and
determined there were inconsistencies with DHHS reports and the family’s self-
report, which led to Worker 1 needed to obtain additional documentation, including
reports from service providers. Additionally, Worker 1 stated that she had concerns
with one of the children in Applicant A & B’s home, which resulted in her obtaining
documents from law enforcement and service providers, which she still had not fully
reviewed at the time of this interview. She added that there is a lot of documentation
to sort through due to the family sometimes providing paperwork in triplicate and
some of the documents not containing consistent information. Additionally, there
were multiple law enforcement and service provider reports for her to sort through
and read, which has added to the delay in completing her report and providing a
recommendation.
At the time of Worker 1’s interview, her home study of Applicants A & B had not yet
been completed. She reported that she was planning to review their paperwork the
day of the interview and was dedicating the next week to completing the report and
expected it to be completed by the end of the week, 7/30/3021.
On 7/22/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 1 in person. She reported that she has been
supervising Worker 1 since May of 2021. She stated that it is not like Worker 1 to be
this late in completing the licensing process and that Worker 1 told Supervisor 1 that
she was overwhelmed by work and had a lot of documents to go through which has
led to the delay. Supervisor 1 stated that she had a conversation with Applicant A
near the end of May 2021 during which she told her she expected the report to be
done by Memorial Day. Supervisor 1 reported that Worker 1 told her that she still
believed the family would be licensable at that time but would require a variance.
Supervisor 1 stated that “more information kept coming out” which led to further
delay and meeting was held with the applicants in June to allow them to self-disclose
information Worker 1 believed them to be withholding. That did not happen so a
meeting was held with DCWL Central Office Consultant who advised Worker 1 to
obtain additional information.
Supervisor 1 stated that she has no concerns with Worker 1 and that the cause of
the excessive timeframe in this case was due to Worker 1 being overworked as
there was a hiring freeze and she was assigned ICPC cases. Supervisor 1 stated
that Worker 1 has worked weekends and nights to complete her work.
On 7/27/2021 I interviewed Program Manager by phone. She stated that she has
had multiple conversations about Applicant A & B’s licensing process with
6

Supervisor 1 and Worker 1. Program Manager stated that discrepancies started to
come out with the information provided by the applicants resulting in the need for
Worker 1 to make a lot of collateral contacts and hundreds of documents for Worker
1 to sort through. Program Manager stated that as Worker 1 sorts through the
documents, additional questions are raised. Program Manager stated that Worker 1
in doing a thorough job of assessing the family. Program Manager stated that
Worker 1 is dedicated and had a lot of work to do around the holidays, including
ICPC cases which were added to her responsibilities.
On July 29, 2021, Director was interviewed by phone. She reported that she met
with Program Manager, Worker 1, and Supervisor 1 after learning of this
investigation and found the length of time the report was taking to be unacceptable.
She stated that unless there is something specific Worker 1 was waiting on, there
should be no reason for the recommendation to take as long as this has. She stated
that it was inappropriate for Worker 1 to tell the family they would be licensed before
making a recommendation and that the denial recommendation should have been
communicated to the family much earlier. Director reported that there was no reason
this family’s case needed to be pushed to the bottom of Worker 1’s priorities and that
it had never come to Director’s attention that the licensing staff were overwhelmed to
the point of being unable to complete tasks timely. Director added that Worker 1 is
typically timely and that it has never taken this long for the agency to license a
family. At the time of the interview, Director 1 reported that she had not yet received
a copy of Worker 1’s report.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12308 Application submission.
(1) An agency shall act on a completed and signed
application.
ANALYSIS: Applicants A & B completed and signed an application on
9/21/2020 after which the family was not enrolled until
2/24/2021. The completed home study with recommendation
was not approved until 8/4/2021. The agency did not actively
work on the completed and signed application due to the length
of time it took to make a recommendation regarding licensure
during which there were periods of time during which no
progress was made.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
CONSULTATION:
During my conversation with Director, I provided consultation regarding the
confusion the family experienced due to Worker 1 communicating to the family that
they would be licensed without completing her assessment of recommendation.
7

Additionally, we discussed the unprofessional conversations with the family about
Worker 1 missing time with her own family so she could work on the family’s
evaluation.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
August 26, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 26, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
